title: adb-app list returns all packages (11K+ chars), no pagination
description:
## Problem
`adb-app list` returns ALL installed packages (~250 packages, ~11K characters) in a single response. No pagination, filtering, or progressive disclosure.

## Evidence
From MCP logs (2026-01-26):
```
[11204 chars truncated]
"count": 250
```

## Expected Behavior
Should support:
1. Pagination or limit parameter
2. Filter by package name pattern
3. Progressive disclosure (list names only → get details)

## Suggested Fix
- Add `limit` parameter (default: 20)
- Add `filter` parameter for package name pattern matching
- Return only package names in list, store full info in cache
- Add `adb-app get-details` for individual package info

title: Switch screenshot format from JPEG to WebP
description:
Replace JPEG encoding with WebP for ~30% size reduction at equivalent quality.

Changes:
- `.jpeg({ quality: 70 })` → `.webp({ quality: 72, effort: 5, smartSubsample: true })`
- Update mimeType from 'image/jpeg' to 'image/webp'

smartSubsample: true preserves text/UI edges better
effort: 5 gives better compression with minimal encode time increase (~50ms)

1. Preserving text edges that would otherwise blur during downscale
2. Allowing lower resolution while maintaining readability
3. Producing cleaner edges that compress better

sigma: 0.5 is subtle—visible improvement without artifacts.

title: Return screenshots as MCP image content blocks instead of text
description:
## Problem

Screenshots are returned as JSON text with embedded base64:
```json
{"type": "text", "text": "{\"base64\": \"...20K chars...\", ...}"}
```

This causes Claude to tokenize the entire base64 string (~5000 tokens for a 15KB image), wasting context and potentially causing session issues in Claude Desktop.

## Solution

Return screenshots using MCP's native image content type:
```json
{
  "content": [
    {"type": "image", "data": "<base64>", "mimeType": "image/jpeg"},
    {"type": "text", "text": "{\"sizeBytes\": 15540, \"device\": {...}}"}
  ]
}
```

## Implementation

In `server.ts`, before line 162, detect if result contains `base64` + `mimeType` fields and split into image + metadata content blocks.

## Affected operations
- `ui screenshot`
- `ui visual-snapshot` (when includeBase64=true)

## Acceptance criteria
- [ ] Screenshots return as `{type: "image"}` content blocks
- [ ] Metadata (sizeBytes, device dimensions, scaleFactor) still returned as text
- [ ] Claude Desktop can view screenshots inline
- [ ] Tests updated

[28109 chars truncated]

title: Android Runtime Diagnostics
description:
Monitor and Diagnose stage capabilities for the agentic flywheel: crash detection, ANR analysis, performance monitoring (memory, jank, battery, network), and enhanced accessibility checks.

These tools give AI agents the ability to detect, diagnose, and understand runtime issues in Android apps — closing the loop between building/deploying and identifying what went wrong.

Key capabilities:
- Structured crash/ANR detection from logcat
- Performance diagnostics via dumpsys (meminfo, gfxinfo, batterystats, netstats)
- Enhanced accessibility-check with actionable issue detection

title: Structured crash detection in adb-logcat
description:
Add a crash-detect operation to adb-logcat that filters for FATAL EXCEPTION, ANR, and SIGABRT patterns, then parses the stack trace into structured JSON:

{ exception, message, stackTrace: [{ class, method, file, line }], causedBy }

This is the highest-leverage monitoring addition — it turns raw logcat noise into actionable crash reports that an AI agent can reason about and suggest fixes for.

Implementation notes:
- Filter logcat for AndroidRuntime FATAL EXCEPTION blocks
- Parse multi-line stack traces into structured format
- Handle chained exceptions (Caused by:)
- Return recent crashes (last N or since timestamp)

title: ANR detection via traces.txt
description:
Read /data/anr/traces.txt when an ANR pattern is detected in logcat. Return structured deadlock/timeout info.

When adb-logcat crash-detect finds an ANR pattern, automatically pull and parse the ANR trace file to provide:
- Thread states and stack traces at time of ANR
- Main thread blocking info
- Deadlock detection (if applicable)
- Structured JSON output matching crash-detect format

Depends on: Structured crash detection in adb-logcat (must be implemented first).

Note: traces.txt access may require root or debuggable app. Handle gracefully when unavailable.

title: dumpsys meminfo wrapper for memory diagnostics
description:
New adb-perf tool operation wrapping dumpsys meminfo <package>. Parse output into structured JSON: heap sizes (native, dalvik, total), allocations, GC stats, object counts.

Key features:
- Parse dumpsys meminfo output for a specific package
- Structured JSON with: nativeHeap, dalvikHeap, totalPss, allocations, gcStats
- Detect potential memory leaks by comparing snapshots (growing native/dalvik heap over time)
- Support baseline comparison mode: take snapshot, run actions, take another, diff

This is one of several adb-perf operations. The adb-perf tool will be a new tool alongside adb-device, adb-app, adb-logcat, etc.

title: dumpsys gfxinfo wrapper for jank detection
description:
adb-perf operation wrapping dumpsys gfxinfo <package>. Parse frame render times, janky frame percentage, and slow UI thread indicators.

Key features:
- Parse dumpsys gfxinfo output into structured JSON
- Report: totalFrames, jankyFrames, jankyPercentage, 50thPercentile, 90thPercentile, 95thPercentile, 99thPercentile
- Detect jank spikes (frames exceeding 16ms threshold)
- Support reset + measure workflow for targeted UI interaction testing

Useful for verifying UI performance after changes — an agent can tap through screens and check for jank regressions.

title: dumpsys batterystats wrapper for power diagnostics
description:
adb-perf operation wrapping dumpsys batterystats. Parse wakelocks, CPU usage by package, and network usage.

Key features:
- Parse dumpsys batterystats output into structured JSON
- Report: wakelocks (name, count, duration), cpuUsage (foreground, background), networkUsage (tx, rx bytes)
- Support reset + measure workflow for targeted battery drain testing
- Highlight anomalies: excessive wakelocks, high background CPU

Lower priority than memory/jank since battery issues are harder to reproduce in emulator environments. Most useful for real device testing.

title: Enhance accessibility-check to detect common UI issues
description:
The current accessibility-check (via ui dump) returns element counts only. Enhance it to detect actionable UI issues:

1. Empty screens: 0 interactive elements (possible loading state or blank screen bug)
2. Missing content descriptions on clickable elements (accessibility violation)
3. Touch target size violations: clickable elements smaller than 48dp x 48dp (Material guidelines)
4. Duplicate content descriptions on sibling elements (confusing for screen readers)

Output structured JSON: { totalElements, issues: [{ type, element, details, severity }] }

This turns the existing accessibility dump into a diagnostic tool that can catch real UI problems, not just count elements.

title: Network traffic monitoring via dumpsys netstats
description:
adb-perf operation for network usage per package via dumpsys netstats.

Key features:
- Parse dumpsys netstats output into structured JSON per package
- Report: txBytes, rxBytes, txPackets, rxPackets, foreground vs background usage
- Support reset + measure workflow for targeted network testing
- Detect anomalies: unexpected network calls, excessive data usage

Useful for detecting apps making unexpected network requests or consuming excessive bandwidth. Lower priority since network issues are often better caught via proxy tools, but useful for quick automated checks.

Parallel Agent Execution System
description:
Design and implement a system for dispatching multiple agents to work on issues in parallel, with the ability to switch context to help stuck agents.

## Vision

User dispatches agents to work on epics/issues. Agents work autonomously in background. When stuck, user can switch to that agent's session, help unblock it, then return to main work.

## Decided So Far

**Dispatch model (Phase 1):** Manual
- User says "work on epic X" → spawns background agent
- User stays in control as dispatcher
- Automated daemon is future work

**Agent work lifecycle:**
```
1. Claim issue: bd update <id> --status=in_progress
2. Check readiness tags ([Needs: design], [Needs: plan])
3. Read linked docs ([Design: path], [Plan: path])
4. Execute work
5. If stuck: signal and wait for user
6. If done: bd close <id> --reason="<summary>"
```

**Stuck/switch model:**
- Agent runs in background (Task tool with run_in_background: true)
- When stuck, agent signals (writes to output, pauses)
- User checks with TaskOutput or switches via resume parameter
- User talks to agent, unblocks it
- User returns to main session (agent continues or user resumes later)

## What Claude Code Already Supports
- `Task` tool with `run_in_background: true` → spawns background agent
- `TaskOutput` → check on agent's progress/output
- `resume` parameter → continue conversation with that agent

## What Needs Design
- How agents signal "stuck" vs "working" vs "done"
- UX for switching between sessions easily
- Agent knowing when to pause vs. retry
- Visibility dashboard (what agents are running, their status)
- How to pass issue context to spawned agents
- Error handling and recovery

## Future: Automated Daemon (Phase 2)
- Watch `bd ready` for available work
- Auto-dispatch agents based on priority/capacity
- Monitor for stuck agents, alert user
- Dashboard for visibility

[Needs: design]

title: Improve gradle-get-details error extraction
description:
gradle-get-details detailType=errors uses simple regex to extract errors from build output: matches lines containing "error:", "Error:", "FAILED", "e:". This is fragile and produces both false positives and false negatives.

Problems:
- False positives: lines containing "error" in variable names, comments, or log messages
- False negatives: misses Kotlin compiler errors that use different formatting, multi-line error messages where only the first line matches, AAPT2 errors with non-standard format
- No context: extracts single lines, losing the surrounding context that makes errors understandable (e.g., "expected X but found Y" without the line of code)

Improvements:
- Use Gradle-aware error parsing: recognize Kotlin compiler error blocks (e: file:line:col format), AAPT2 errors, resource merge failures, dependency resolution errors
- Extract error blocks (not just single lines) — include 1-2 lines of context around each error
- Categorize errors by type: compilation, resource, dependency, configuration
- Return structured format: { type, file, line, message, context } instead of raw strings

File: src/tools/gradle-get-details.ts (error extraction logic in the detailType=errors branch)

Parent epic for work identified in the Agentic Flywheel evaluation (see ../agentic-flywheel-eval-replicant-mcp.md).

The flywheel has four stages: Release > Monitor > Diagnose > Fix. Release and Fix are production-ready/functional. Monitor and Diagnose are scaffolded at best — the cycle breaks because there's no signal from production back to the maintainer.

Goal: Connect the existing structured error system (40+ ErrorCodes in src/types/errors.ts) to aggregate signals so the flywheel can spin. Priority order: telemetry beacon > post-publish smoke test > issue intake automation > error-code changelog > low-risk fix fast lane.

[Needs: design]

title: Opt-in error telemetry beacon
description:
[Needs: design]

## Summary
When a ReplicantError fires, optionally send a minimal, anonymized payload to a lightweight endpoint. This is the single highest-leverage item for closing the Monitor-Diagnose gap.

## Flywheel Stage
Monitor + Diagnose (connects Release to Diagnose)

## Problem
The structured error system (40+ ErrorCodes in src/types/errors.ts) produces rich, machine-readable error context — but it evaporates after the user's session ends. The maintainer has zero visibility into what errors are happening across the user base, at what frequency, or correlated with which release.

## What to Design

### Payload shape
Minimal, anonymized. Candidate fields:
- error_code (e.g., DEVICE_OFFLINE, BUILD_FAILED)
- tool_name (e.g., adb-device, gradle-build)
- replicant_mcp_version (e.g., 1.4.8)
- os_platform (e.g., darwin, linux, win32)
- android_version (if detectable from connected device)
- timestamp (ISO 8601)
- NO PII, no file paths, no stderr content, no device serial

### Opt-in mechanism
MCP servers run inside Claude Desktop/Code. Design decisions needed:
- How does a user opt in? Environment variable? First-run prompt? Config file?
- What's the default? (Must be opt-in, not opt-out, for trust.)
- How does the user opt back out?
- Should the MCP client (Claude) be involved in consent, or is it server-side only?

### Transport
Where do payloads go? Evaluate tradeoffs:
- **GitHub Actions dispatch**: Free, in-ecosystem, but rate-limited and not real-time
- **Cloudflare Worker + D1/R2**: Cheap, fast, requires infrastructure
- **JSONL file in repo on a branch**: Zero-cost but noisy git history
- **Sentry/PostHog free tier**: Mature tooling but external dependency
- Consider: What's the simplest thing that gives us error-code frequency by version?

### Consumption
How does a maintainer (or agent) read the signals?
- Dashboard? CLI query? Raw data?
- What query patterns matter? (e.g., "error rate for DEVICE_OFFLINE in v1.4.8 vs v1.4.7")
- Should there be alerting? (e.g., "error rate spiked 3x after latest release")

### Privacy and trust
- Document what's collected and what's not
- Add to README or a TELEMETRY.md
- Consider: npm ecosystem norms for CLI telemetry (Next.js, Turborepo, etc. as precedent)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Design doc in docs/plans/ covering payload, opt-in, transport, consumption
- [ ] Privacy policy drafted
- [ ] ReplicantError.toJSON() or similar produces the beacon payload
- [ ] Telemetry is disabled by default, enabled via explicit opt-in
- [ ] At least one consumption path works (even if it's just a JSONL file)
- [ ] Tests cover: opt-in/out, payload shape, no PII leakage, transport failure handling

title: Post-publish smoke test in CI
description:
[Needs: design]

## Summary
After npm publish succeeds in the release workflow, add a CI step that installs the just-published package, starts the MCP server, and verifies it works.

## Flywheel Stage
Release + Monitor (closes gap between "release succeeded" and "release works")

## Problem
Today, the release workflow (.github/workflows/release.yml) publishes to npm and creates a GitHub Release, but never verifies the published package actually works. A broken dist/, missing file in package.json#files, or bad entry point would ship silently. The first signal would be a user report days later.

## What to Design

### Smoke test scope
What's the minimum verification that catches real failures?
- Install from npm registry: npm install replicant-mcp@<just-published-version>
- Start MCP server (stdio mode) and send ListTools request
- Verify expected tool count (currently 12)
- Verify server responds to a basic CallTool (e.g., cache get-stats, which needs no Android device)
- Timeout: if server doesn't respond in 30s, fail

### Existing code to reuse
- tests/integration/mcp-protocol.test.ts already tests ListTools and tool count
- The test spawns the server via @modelcontextprotocol/sdk Client
- Challenge: this test runs against local dist/, not the published npm package
- Design: extract the protocol test into a standalone script that can target either local or published package

### CI integration
- Where in release.yml? After the npm-publish step, before (or alongside) gh-release
- Failure handling: if smoke test fails AFTER publish, the package is already on npm. Options:
  - npm unpublish (risky, only works within 72h, breaks dependents)
  - npm deprecate (safer, warns users)
  - Just fail the workflow and alert (simplest — human decides)
- Consider: should this be a separate workflow triggered after release.yml completes?

### npm registry propagation delay
- npm publish is not instant globally. Design must handle:
  - Retry with backoff (e.g., try install 3 times over 60s)
  - Or pin to registry URL that's consistent

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Design doc covering scope, failure handling, registry delay mitigation
- [ ] CI step added to release.yml (or new workflow)
- [ ] Installs published package (not local build)
- [ ] Verifies MCP server starts and responds to ListTools
- [ ] Handles npm propagation delay gracefully
- [ ] Clear failure message if smoke test fails post-publish
- [ ] Documented in CLAUDE.md releasing section

title: GitHub Issue intake automation
description:
[Needs: design]

## Summary
A GitHub Actions workflow triggered on new issues that auto-triages by extracting error codes, labeling by tool category, and linking to previous fixes.

## Flywheel Stage
Monitor + Diagnose + Fix (accelerates the gap between user report and agent action)

## Problem
Issue triage is fully manual today. When a user files a GitHub Issue, a maintainer must:
1. Read the full issue
2. Identify which tool is affected
3. Look up if this error has been seen before
4. Create a beads issue
5. Start investigating

This can take days. With structured error codes already in the product (40+ ErrorCodes), pattern-matching on issue bodies is straightforward and should be automated.

## What to Design

### Issue parsing
- Regex patterns to extract ErrorCode values from issue body (e.g., SDK_NOT_FOUND, BUILD_FAILED, DEVICE_OFFLINE)
- Extract replicant-mcp version if mentioned
- Extract OS/platform if mentioned
- Handle: user pastes full JSON error output vs. just describes the error in prose

### Auto-labeling
Map ErrorCode prefixes to labels:
- DEVICE_*, ADB_* → label: tool/adb
- BUILD_*, GRADLE_* → label: tool/gradle
- EMULATOR_* → label: tool/emulator
- SDK_*, ENVIRONMENT_* → label: env/setup
- UI_* → label: tool/ui
- Create labels if they don't exist (first-run bootstrap)

### Historical linking
- Search closed issues for the same ErrorCode
- If found, comment: "This error was previously reported in #N and fixed in PR #M"
- If the telemetry beacon (issue #1) exists, also include: "This error has been reported N times in the last 7 days"

### Issue template
- Create .github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml with structured fields:
  - Error code (dropdown of common ones + "other")
  - Tool name (dropdown)
  - replicant-mcp version
  - OS
  - Steps to reproduce
  - Full error output (textarea)
- This makes parsing more reliable

### Beads integration (stretch)
- Auto-create a beads issue when a GitHub Issue is labeled as a confirmed bug
- Or: comment with a suggested bd create command the maintainer can copy

## Dependencies
- Benefits significantly from telemetry beacon (issue #1) for frequency data
- Works without it, but historical linking is limited to GitHub Issues only

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Design doc covering parsing strategy, label taxonomy, historical linking approach
- [ ] GitHub Actions workflow triggers on issues.opened
- [ ] Extracts ErrorCode from issue body (handles JSON and prose)
- [ ] Applies tool-category labels
- [ ] Comments with links to related closed issues if found
- [ ] Bug report issue template created
- [ ] Tested with sample issues containing various error formats

title: Error-code changelog in releases
description:
[Needs: design]

## Summary
Auto-generate an "Error Handling Changes" section in release notes by diffing src/types/errors.ts between tags.

## Flywheel Stage
Diagnose + Release (makes regressions immediately visible)

## Problem
When diagnosing a regression, the first question is "what changed?" Today, an agent must read commit history and manually diff error handling code. If v1.4.8 changed the BUILD_FAILED context format or removed an error suggestion, this could break downstream parsing or confuse users — but it's invisible in auto-generated release notes.

## What to Design

### Diff strategy
- Compare src/types/errors.ts between the previous tag and the new tag
- Detect:
  - New ErrorCodes added
  - ErrorCodes removed
  - ErrorCode enum value changes
  - Changes to default suggestions (if extractable)
- Output as a markdown section suitable for GitHub Release body

### Implementation options
1. **Shell script in release.sh**: Parse the diff with awk/grep, append to release notes
   - Pro: No new dependencies, fits existing script pattern
   - Con: Fragile parsing of TypeScript enums
2. **TypeScript script**: Import/require the errors module from both versions, compare programmatically
   - Pro: Reliable, type-safe
   - Con: Need to build both versions, more complex
3. **GitHub Actions step**: Run diff in CI during release workflow
   - Pro: Runs after tag is pushed, has access to both versions via git
   - Con: Release notes are created by softprops/action-gh-release — need to inject content

### Release notes integration
- Current flow: softprops/action-gh-release@v2 with generate_release_notes: true
- Options to add error changelog:
  - Prepend to auto-generated notes via the body parameter
  - Use a separate step to update the release after creation (gh release edit)
  - Template the release notes instead of auto-generating

### Example output
```markdown
## Error Handling Changes
- **Added**: `UI_SCREENSHOT_FAILED` - New error for screenshot capture failures
- **Modified**: `BUILD_FAILED` - Updated suggestion text to include Gradle 8.x guidance
- **Removed**: `DEVICE_NOT_SELECTED` - Merged into `DEVICE_OFFLINE`
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Design doc covering diff strategy and integration point
- [ ] Script/action generates error-code diff between tags
- [ ] Output included in GitHub Release notes
- [ ] Handles: no changes (omit section), first release (list all codes)
- [ ] Tested with mock tag diffs

title: Low-risk fix fast lane
description:
[Needs: design]

## Summary
Define criteria for "trivial fixes" that can auto-merge after CI passes + Greptile finds no critical issues, bypassing the human merge gate.

## Flywheel Stage
Fix + Release (tightens the cycle for safe repairs)

## Problem
Today, every fix — from a typo in an error suggestion to a major architectural change — goes through the same PR workflow: create PR, wait for Greptile, wait for human approval, merge, then manually trigger release. This is correct for most changes, but it means the flywheel can't spin on low-risk fixes without a human online.

Once telemetry is flowing (issue #1) and issues are triaged automatically (issue #3), the bottleneck shifts from detection to shipping. Having a fast lane for safe fixes lets the flywheel spin tighter.

## What to Design

### Trivial fix criteria
Define what qualifies. Candidate rules (all must be true):
- Diff < N lines (e.g., 20)
- Only touches allowed paths:
  - src/types/errors.ts (suggestion text only, not error codes)
  - docs/**
  - README.md
  - CLAUDE.md
  - .github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/**
- Does NOT touch: src/tools/*, src/services/*, src/adapters/*, src/server.ts, tests/**
- All CI checks pass (tests, complexity, lint)
- Greptile review has zero critical findings
- Branch prefix is trivial/ (already exists for beads exemption)

### Auto-merge mechanism
Options:
1. **GitHub branch protection rule**: Enable auto-merge when all checks pass for trivial/ branches
   - Pro: Native GitHub, simple
   - Con: Can't enforce Greptile severity filtering in branch rules
2. **GitHub Actions workflow**: On check_suite.completed for trivial/ branches, verify criteria and call gh pr merge
   - Pro: Full control over criteria
   - Con: More complex, needs testing
3. **Greptile webhook + Actions**: Wait for Greptile comment, parse severity, merge if clean
   - Pro: Respects review quality
   - Con: Greptile timing is unpredictable

### Safety rails
- Never auto-merge to master if tests are red
- Log all auto-merges to a JSONL audit file (or beads note)
- Allow human to add "hold" label to prevent auto-merge
- Rate limit: max N auto-merges per day (prevents runaway agent)
- Revert mechanism: if post-merge CI fails, auto-create revert PR

### Release integration
Should a fast-lane fix auto-trigger a patch release?
- If yes: after merge, auto-run npm run release (patch only)
- If no: batch trivial fixes and release manually
- Consider: too many patch releases is noisy for users on npm

## Dependencies
- Telemetry beacon (issue #1): needed to define "low-risk" based on error frequency
- Issue intake automation (issue #3): feeds the bug stream that fast-lane serves
- Works without them but is less impactful (fewer issues flowing through the pipe)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Design doc covering criteria, mechanism, safety rails, release integration
- [ ] Criteria codified in a script or action (not just documented)
- [ ] Auto-merge tested on a trivial/ branch PR
- [ ] Safety: hold label prevents merge, rate limit enforced
- [ ] Audit trail for all auto-merges
- [ ] DECISIONS.md entry for the chosen approach
- [ ] Human can always override (reject, hold, or manually merge)

title: ui find text matching has gaps - falls to tier 4 unnecessarily
description:
During stress testing, `ui find` failed to match text that was clearly present in the accessibility dump:

**Examples:**
1. `find { textContains: 'Promoted Pin' }` → 0 results, fell to tier 4
   - But dump showed: `'Promoted Pin by Xfinity: >Pin from ad.doubleclick.net...'`

2. `find { text: 'Saved' }` → 0 results, fell to tier 4
   - But dump showed: `{ text: 'Saved', resourceId: 'profile_menu_view' }`

**Expected:** Should match at tier 1 (accessibility) since text exists in tree.

**Possible causes:**
- Text matching not checking all node fields (text, contentDesc, etc.)
- Case sensitivity issues
- Partial match logic not working for `textContains`

[Needs: investigation]

- Update instructions to match actual behavior

title: App launch with explicit intents and deep links
description:
Extend adb-app launch beyond the current monkey command approach. Support launching apps with:

- intent: explicit intent URI
- action: intent action (e.g., android.intent.action.VIEW)
- data: URI data (deep links, custom schemes)
- extras: key-value intent extras (string, int, bool, etc.)

- Testing deep link handling
- Navigating directly to specific screens
- Passing test data via intent extras
- Launching specific activities that aren't the main entry point

Implementation: use am start with appropriate flags instead of monkey.

title: ui find fallback grid image is 151K+ chars PNG, destroys context
description:
## Problem
When `ui find` can't locate an element (tier 5, low confidence), it returns a huge PNG grid image (~151K characters of base64). This single fallback response can exhaust the context window.

## Evidence
From MCP logs (2026-01-26):
```json
{
  "elements": [],
  "count": 0,
  "tier": 5,
  "confidence": "low",
  "gridImage": "iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAcIAAAPoCAYAAABNsP48AAA...[151041 chars truncated]...
}
```

## Expected Behavior
Grid image should be:
1. Optional (off by default, enabled via parameter)
2. JPEG compressed (not PNG)
3. Scaled down appropriately

## Suggested Fix
- Add `includeGridImage: boolean` parameter (default: false)
- Convert grid image to JPEG
- Scale to reasonable dimensions
- Or: return grid image as cache ID, fetch separately if needed

## Impact
This single tool response used more context than 4 screenshots combined.
notes: PR: https://github.com/thecombatwombat/replicant-mcp/pull/43

title: Standardize tool errors to ReplicantError
description:
Several tool handlers throw generic Error on validation/unknown ops, which bypasses ReplicantError and can surface as unstructured failures.

Files: src/tools/adb-app.ts, adb-device.ts, ui.ts, emulator-device.ts, cache.ts, gradle-list.ts.

Fix: replace generic Error throws with ReplicantError + appropriate ErrorCode (add codes if needed) so tool responses are consistent (isError + ToolError shape).
notes:
## Agent Spec
- **Branch:** fix/replicant-errors
- **Wave:** 1
- **Files edit:** src/types/errors.ts (add 3 ErrorCodes), src/tools/emulator-device.ts (9 throws), src/tools/adb-app.ts (6), src/tools/adb-device.ts (3), src/tools/ui.ts (5), src/tools/ui-find.ts (1), src/tools/cache.ts (1), src/tools/gradle-list.ts (1)
- **Implementation:** Add ErrorCodes: INPUT_VALIDATION_FAILED, INVALID_OPERATION, ELEMENT_NOT_FOUND to src/types/errors.ts. Convert all 26 throw new Error() to throw new ReplicantError(ErrorCode.X, msg, suggestion). Pattern: parameter validation -> INPUT_VALIDATION_FAILED, unknown operation -> INVALID_OPERATION, ui element not found -> ELEMENT_NOT_FOUND, device not found -> DEVICE_NOT_FOUND (existing). ReplicantError extends Error so existing catches still work.
- **Tests:** tests/tools/error-standardization.test.ts — verify each tool's validation throws produce ReplicantError with correct code
- **Pre-PR:** npm run test:coverage (all 4 thresholds must pass)

4. Is this actually more composable or just another layer of complexity?

- Skills provide value beyond raw MCP tools
- Don't duplicate logic (skills orchestrate, don't reimplement)
- Clear boundary between tool layer (MCP) and workflow layer (Skills)

title: Investigate cross-project decision knowledge base via qmd + MCP
description:
Investigate using qmd (github.com/tobi/qmd) or similar as a centralized decision knowledge base across all projects, exposed via MCP.

## Vision
A single qmd service that indexes DECISIONS.md files (and eventually ADRs) across ALL projects. Exposed via MCP so any Claude Code session in any project can query 'has this decision been made before?' across the entire portfolio.

## Key Questions
- Can qmd run as a persistent service (not just CLI)?
- How to expose it as an MCP server (qmd already has MCP support)?
- Single instance indexing multiple repos vs per-repo instances?
- How to handle cross-project decision discovery (e.g., a pattern chosen in project A informs project B)?
- What's the minimum viable setup? Just DECISIONS.md files + qmd MCP?

## Architecture Sketch
```
[Project A] --MCP--> [qmd service] <--MCP-- [Project B]
    |                     |                      |
DECISIONS.md    indexes all repos        DECISIONS.md
```

## Prior Art
- qmd by Tobi Lütke: hybrid search (BM25 + vectors + LLM re-ranking)
- Already has MCP support
- Runs locally (no cloud dependency)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Evaluate qmd MCP capabilities
- [ ] Prototype single-service multi-repo indexing
- [ ] Define DECISIONS.md format that works well with qmd chunking
- [ ] Document setup for adding new projects to the index

[Needs: design]

title: Evaluate qmd MCP server capabilities
description: Install qmd, test its MCP server mode. Understand: what search modes are available via MCP, how collections/indexes work, what the query interface looks like for an LLM consumer. Document findings.

title: Prototype multi-repo qmd index
description: Set up qmd indexing DECISIONS.md across 2+ repos. Test cross-project queries. Evaluate search quality and latency. Determine if single instance or per-repo is better.

title: Design MCP integration for Claude Code projects
description: Design the .mcp.json configuration that each project would use to connect to the shared qmd service. Consider: how projects register their DECISIONS.md, how to handle project-specific vs cross-cutting decisions, auth/access model.

title: Fix path error: process.cwd() returns / in Claude Desktop sandbox
description:
**Problem:** In Claude Desktop's sandboxed environment, process.cwd() returns '/' causing:
```
ENOENT: no such file or directory, mkdir '/.replicant/screenshots'
```

**Root cause:** getDefaultScreenshotPath() uses process.cwd() which is '/' in sandbox.

**Solution:** Use os.homedir() as fallback when cwd is '/':
```typescript
const baseDir = process.cwd() === '/' ? os.homedir() : process.cwd();
```

**Files:** src/adapters/ui-automator.ts (getDefaultScreenshotPath function)
